ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course strengthened my understanding of what I had learned previously about quantum mechanics and also introduced me to new information on the topic, like applying certain quantum mechanical models to more than one dimension.
This course improved my understanding of quantum mechanical systems that I had learned about in physical chemistry. My physical and mathematical intuition greatly improved.
I got a nice refresher of some of the concepts I've seen in previous QM courses, and learned a few new things along the way.
We learned the fundamentals of quantum mechanics, including how to derive and solve problems related to fundamental quantum systems. We learned both the math and the physics behind the systems.

Basics of quantum and how to apply it to specific occasions

Math, physics and analytical thinking
QM

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very well-organized and proceeds very logically. All necessary math not taught in another required course is explained in careful detail.
One strength is that the course was very well-organized. I always knew what was going to be taught on a given day and what was expected of me.

Professor Hammes-Schiffer explains tricky mathematical concepts clearly. She works through the most important steps of a problem with the class, and she dives into the more detailed steps if someone asks. She manages to pack a lot into her 75 minute classes!
great course overall!
I thought weekly homework was reasonable length so we could review the week's material, but not take too long.

The strengths of the class were the in-class problems and examples to help us understand. The course focused on both the math and the theory behind the math to create a good understanding of the topics. The weakness of the course was that the quantum derivations were very math-heavy and hard to understand. This could be improved by going through the derivations more slowly and explaining each step in greater detail.

The course grading and exams were extremely fair. The instructor makes fairness a priority. I like that.

The course could be made more challenging. The homework was very easy, including the optional problems, and I felt that harder problems would have helped me learn more.
lots of practice

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! This course does a great job of logically going through basics of quantum mechanics, and is presented in a way that makes it very interesting and easy to follow.
Yes. Although I came into this course with some background, I feel like I still could have understood the concepts as they were taught, even without that background.

Yes! This is a great follow-up to physical chemistry II. The concepts in 466 are similar to those in CHEM 332, and it's really useful to see them taught from another professor. It helps you understand the concepts and math in a new way.
Well structured and clearly explained
yes, if you want to learn about quantum mechanics! the math isn't too bad at all. if you're not interested in the material at least a little it will be hard to follow along.
Yes, overall it is a good refresher if you have some background. And I feel like it's doable even if it's the first quantum class you take since it gets the fundamentals.
I would recommend this course because it provides a good foundation to understand quantum mechanics.
Yes, it was well structured and clear
If you're capable of self-studying, then no. You'd learn more and have better retention by doing it yourself.
yes, good intro
